title: 109_s2255
content: The Act titled "Medicare Drug Formulary Protection Act" allows for the removal of covered Part D drugs from the prescription drug plan formulary. The Medicare Drug Formulary Protection Act prohibits the removal or restriction of covered Part D drugs from the prescription drug plan formulary starting in 2006. The Medicare Drug Formulary Protection Act prohibits the removal or restriction of covered Part D drugs from the prescription drug plan formulary, except for certain circumstances allowed by the Secretary. Newly enrolled individuals are also protected from drug removal or coverage restrictions by the PDP sponsor. The Medicare Drug Formulary Protection Act prohibits the removal or restriction of covered Part D drugs from the prescription drug plan formulary, except for specific circumstances allowed by the Secretary. This protection extends to newly enrolled individuals until December 31 of the following plan year, with exceptions for new therapeutic uses and newly covered Part D drugs. The Medicare Drug Formulary Protection Act prohibits the removal or restriction of covered Part D drugs from the prescription drug plan formulary, except for specific circumstances allowed by the Secretary. This includes brand name drugs going off-patent, drugs with FDA-imposed restrictions, and drugs deemed ineffective during the specified period. PDP sponsors must provide notice of any removal under these exceptions. The Medicare Drug Formulary Protection Act requires PDP sponsors to give annual notice of changes in formulary or coverage restrictions to enrollees during the coordinated election period. The Medicare Drug Formulary Protection Act requires PDP sponsors to provide annual notice of formulary changes during coordinated election periods starting after the enactment of the Act.
